title: Html Injection and Possible XSS in sms-be-vip.twitter.com

activities.message:
Thank you for your report.

Per our program rules, vulnerabilities only affecting users of outdated or unpatched browsers and platforms are not eligible for our bug bounty program.

Please see https://hackerone.com/twitter for full program rules and exclusions.

Thank you for thinking of Twitter Security!

activities.message:
Hey,
Thanks for your reply, but i'm sorry i have to disagree and I do have some concerns regarding this.

You said the following:
>  Per our program rules, vulnerabilities only affecting users of outdated or unpatched browsers and platforms are not eligible for our bug bounty program.

I want to clarify that **Internet Explorer 11** isn't an outdated or unpatched browser. It's the latest browser version supported on **Windows  7**, **Windows 8** , **Windows 9** . i don't think these versions of windows are  considered an outdated platforms by Microsoft.

Still there are millions of users who still use Windows 7 and Windows 8 and **Internet Explorer 11** is the latest version on these versions of windows platforms with latest windows updates. So obviously millions of users would be vulnerable to the attack and the vulnerability i've mentioned here.

Also if  you see Google's Vulnerability Reward Program at:
https://www.google.com.eg/about/appsecurity/reward-program/

You will notice that Google Engineers says the following:

>  **Non-qualifying vulnerabilities:** 
Flaws affecting the users of out-of-date browsers and plugins. The security model of the web is being constantly fine-tuned. The panel will typically not reward any problems that affect only the users of outdated or unpatched browsers. In particular, we exclude Internet Explorer prior to version 9. 

So Google Security Engineers will accept any bugs that affects Internet explorer 9 , 10 , 11.

I would be very glad if you can re-evaluate/re-consider the report.

Thanks in advance!

activities.message:
While this report is comprehensive and there's some concern around it, it will be closed as Informative because:
> Note: This XSS POC will work only if the XSS Auditor is disabled in Internet Explorer.

and we expect users to have a reasonable amount of protection around their devices and computers used to access Twitter.

But I do appreciate the comprehensive nature of the write-up and the depth of detail it contains! Thank you for that!
activities.markdown_message:
While this report is comprehensive and there's some concern around it, it will be closed as Informative because:

Note: This XSS POC will work only if the XSS Auditor is disabled in Internet Explorer.

and we expect users to have a reasonable amount of protection around their devices and computers used to access Twitter.

But I do appreciate the comprehensive nature of the write-up and the depth of detail it contains! Thank you for that!

activities.message:
Thanks a lot @bfd  for your reply. 

Well i thought demonstrating the HTML injection will be considered an acceptable risk to the users ,as an attacker could trick them into a phishing web page on Twitter domain. But i do agree with you that HTML injection without executing Javascript isn't severe.

**So i've made another XSS POC that works on MSIE 11 and will fully bypass the XSS Auditor.**

The POC will execute javascript on the same context of ```sms-be-vip.twitter.com```

##POC:
https://secgeek.net/POC/Twitter-XSS-POC.html

#POC Details:

The POC will execute the following javascript code on ```sms-be-vip.twitter.com```:
```html
<script>eval(atob('YWxlcnQoJ1hTUyBQT0MnKTthbGVydCgnRG9tYWluOiAnK2RvY3VtZW50LmRvbWFpbik7YWxlcnQoJ1lvdXIgQ29va2llczpcbicrZG9jdW1lbnQuY29va2llKTt0b3AubG9jYXRpb24uaHJlZj0naHR0cDovL2V4YW1wbGUuY29tJzs='))<\/script>
```

The Base64 value of the payload is:
```
alert('XSS POC');alert('Domain: '+document.domain);alert('Your Cookies:\n'+document.cookie);top.location.href='http://example.com';
```

So the POC will execute 3 JavaScript statements in sequence .

1. Alert for ``document.domain```
2. Alert for ```document.cookie```
3. Redirect to ```http://example.com```

I've attached also the XSS POC code.

Kindly check and review it.
Thanks in advance!

alert('XSS POC');alert('Domain: '+document.domain);alert('Your Cookies:\n'+document.cookie);top.location.href='http://example.com';

So the POC will execute 3 JavaScript statements in sequence .

  1. Alert for document.domain`
  2. Alert for document.cookie

vulnerability_information_html:
Hi,
I would like to report HTML Injection and possible cross site scripting (XSS) vulnerability in sms-be-vip.twitter.com

Overview

The sms-be-vip.twitter.com 404 error page appears to be vulnerable to XSS and HTML Injection as it doesn't encode the HTML tags in the path name such as https://sms-be-vip.twitter.com/<h1>TEST</h1>.

But the HTML tags have to be send without URL encoding. Most of the modern web browsers will encode the HTML tags in the request before it being sent to the webserver. However In Internet Explorer 11 and lower versions it's possible to make the browser send the request without any URL encoding.

How to make MSIE 7 - 11 send the request without URL encoding ?

Internet Explorer won't encode the URL if it was sent from a 302 Redirect.

So you can use a simple PHP page like the following:

<?php
$url = $_GET['x'];
header("Location: $url");
?>

Then use the page and perform a redirection to the endpoint which is vulenrable to XSS.

http://secgeek.net/POC/redir.php?x=https://sms-be-vip.twitter.com/<h1>TEST</h1>

Now you could notice that the friendly HTTP error messages in Internet Explorer will appear instead of showing the <h1>TEST</h1> in the error page.

There is a simple workaround for this issue.
According to Microsoft the HTTP friendly error message will appears if it meets two criteria

1.The HTTP Status code must be [400, 403, 404, 405, 406, 408, 409, 410, 500, 501, 505]
2.The HTTP Response body’s byte length must be shorter than a threshold value

 The default threshold value for 404 errors is 512 bytes.

So we can add more data in the request to be returned in the server response that will overcome this issue.

http://secgeek.net/POC/redir.php?x=https://sms-be-vip.twitter.com/<h1>TEST</h1>....................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................

Techincal Details

Impact:

The vulnerability allow a malicious user to inject html tags and execute Javascript in the same context of sms-be-vip.twitter.com domain which could lead to steal user's session, peform CSRF attacks or open a phishing page.

Affected Domain:

sms-be-vip.twitter.com

Affected Insertion point:

The path name in the url https://sms-be-vip.twitter.com/<XSS Injection here>

HTML Injection POC

http://secgeek.net/POC/Twitter-HTML-POC.php

XSS POC

http://secgeek.net/POC/Twitter-XSS-POC.php

Note: This XSS POC will work only if the XSS Auditor is disabled in Internet Explorer.

I've Attached Sreenshots for the two POCs.

Kindly check and review the issue.
Thanks in advance!
